interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Legendary Performances
Review Date: 2014/04/02
Store: Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Music Videos & Concerts
Product Description: ['From the vaults of the Country Music Hall Of Fame and Museum, this collection features nearly two decades of Merle Haggard performances in his prime not seen since their original broadcast. Now, for the first time on DVD, experience the hits through a chronology of vintage live performances such as "Branded Man" (Country Music Holiday,1968), "Mama Tried" (Billy Walker\'s Country Carnival, 1968) and "Okie From Muskogee" (The Porter Wagoner Show, 1970). When Merle Haggard left prison in 1960, he went on to achieve 38 #1 hits (to date) and establish himself as one of the greats in country music. But getting out of prison didn\'t quite mean leaving his rebel ways behind. His songwriting depicted the truths of a rough-and-tumble life which he fused with a musical style derived from hardcore country, jazz, blues and folk to create a sound no one had ever heard, with lyrics many could relate to. From the walls of San Quentin to his free-spirited life as an irreverent and unique voice outside the Nashville establishment to his induction in the Country Music Hall of Fame, Merle Haggard has never left a doubt that he is country\'s original outlaw.']
Average Rating: 4.4
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Merle Haggard Legendary Performances, Country', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, NTSC', 'Contributor': 'Merle Haggard', 'Language': 'English', 'Number Of Discs': '1', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.33:1', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '5.4 x 7.5 x 0.6 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': 'DVD0808001', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Color, NTSC', 'Run time': '1 hour and 5 minutes', 'Release date': 'November 11, 2008', 'Actors': 'Merle Haggard', 'Studio': 'SHOUT! FACTORY', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: I was not to thrilled with this dvd. Some of the audio and the visual was not clear. Did not cost that much so maybe I should not complain, but would not buy another one, for sure.
Review Title: Not to thrilled
Rating: 2.0
--------------------------------------------------

Live At The US Festival, 1983
Rated:    Unrated    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Music Videos & Concerts
["Waylon Jennings appeared at the US Festival on June 4, 1983. It was billed as Country Day, with Waylon performing alongside such artists as Willie Nelson, Alabama, Hank Williams, Jr.., and Emmylou Harris. Waylon's performance was one of the day's many highlights, and he is joined onstage by wife Jessi Colter for a particularly memorable rendition of 'Storms Never Last.' the US Festival was held over two weekends in 1982 and 1983. Steve Wozniak, cofounder of Apple Computer, funded the concerts and accompanying technology exposition, as well as the construction of a brand-new outdoor venue in Glen Helen Regional Park in San Bernadino, CA. Nearly every musical genre was represented by bands as diverse as U2, Fleetwood Mac, David Bowie, Ozzy Osbourne, Willie Nelson, Van Halen, the Police and the Clash. Over the combined seven days of the festival, more than one million people passed through the entrance gates."]

Legendary Performances
Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Music Videos & Concerts
['From the vaults of the Country Music Hall Of Fame and Museum, this collection features nearly two decades of Merle Haggard performances in his prime not seen since their original broadcast. Now, for the first time on DVD, experience the hits through a chronology of vintage live performances such as "Branded Man" (Country Music Holiday,1968), "Mama Tried" (Billy Walker\'s Country Carnival, 1968) and "Okie From Muskogee" (The Porter Wagoner Show, 1970). When Merle Haggard left prison in 1960, he went on to achieve 38 #1 hits (to date) and establish himself as one of the greats in country music. But getting out of prison didn\'t quite mean leaving his rebel ways behind. His songwriting depicted the truths of a rough-and-tumble life which he fused with a musical style derived from hardcore country, jazz, blues and folk to create a sound no one had ever heard, with lyrics many could relate to. From the walls of San Quentin to his free-spirited life as an irreverent and unique voice outside the Nashville establishment to his induction in the Country Music Hall of Fame, Merle Haggard has never left a doubt that he is country\'s original outlaw.']

profile:
The user maintains a strong passion for classic country music, continuously appreciating the works of legendary artists. Despite their recent purchase of a classic performance DVD, their experience was less than satisfactory, as they expressed disappointment in the audio and visual quality, which contrasts with their usual standards for authentic concert experiences. This interaction highlights a nuanced perspective; while they are eager to explore iconic performances, quality remains paramount.

Their overall preference for high-quality content in the classic country genre underscores their commitment to genuine artistry and live experiences. The user's positive feedback in previous interactions emphasizes their enjoyment of memorable and compelling performances, showcasing their community-oriented mindset by actively sharing recommendations with fellow fans.

Key trends include:
- **Genre Preference**: A focused interest in classic country music and its influential artists.
- **Media Format**: A tendency towards DVDs for immersive experiences, though cautious of quality.
- **Content Enjoyment**: Strong inclination for engaging and authentic performances, reflecting their disappointment in less clear recordings.
- **Recommendation Behavior**: An active participant in the country music community, eager to share both positive experiences and cautionary insights about content.

Overall, the user values high-quality performances, authenticity in their music choices, and meaningful connections with fellow enthusiasts. Their recent experience serves as a reminder of the importance they place on quality in their entertainment selections.
